sen.j: 民党（みんとう）とは、明治時代の自由民権運動を推進してきた自由党_(明治)・立憲改進党などの民権派各党の総称。
sen.e: Minto is the general term of the political parties such as the Liberal Party (in the Meiji period) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and so on which promoted the Movement for Democratic Rights in the Meiji Period.
sen.cmt: 政党名の訳語は『研究社新和英大辞典』に依りました。
sen.e: Minto is the general term of the political parties such as the Liberal Party (in the Meiji period) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and so on which promoted the Movement for Democratic Rights in the Meiji Period.

sen.j: 主に帝国議会開設から日清戦争にかけて使われてきたが、その後も「民衆代表政党」の意味を込めて大正期まで使われてきた。
sen.e: It was used mainly between the establishment of the Imperial Diet and the First Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895, after that, it was also used to the Taisho Period with the meaning of "the Parties of the People's Representatives."
sen.cmt: 「日清戦争」について： 年号を付けない場合もありますが、読者の理解を助けるために付けました。
sen.e: It was used mainly between the establishment of the Imperial Diet and the First Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895, but was used to the Taisho period with the meaning of "the Parties of the People's Representatives" afterwards.
sen.cmt: 文章を滑らかにしました。

sen.j: 第1回衆議院議員総選挙で合計すると、衆議院の過半数を制した自由党（当時は分裂状態にあり、大同団結運動を経て再統合される）や立憲改進党などの民権派各党は、世論の意思は自分たちにあると捉え、自分達を弾圧してきた藩閥政府やその同調者と見られた保守系政党（大成会など）との対決姿勢を強めた。
sen.e: Winning a majority in the first general election of the members of the House of Representatives in 1890, the parties demanding the democratic rights such as the Liberal Party (it was split then and reunited through the Great Merger Movement) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and so on thought that the public was on their side and strengthened the attitude toward the han-dominated government (the members of former Choshu and Satsuma domains who played major part in the Meiji Restoration and had power after the restoration) which had suppressed them and toward other conservative parties (the Taiseikai Group and so on) which were regarded as the followers of the government.
sen.cmt: (1)読者の理解のために、「第一回衆議院議員総選挙」の訳に西暦を補足しました。不要な場合は削除してください。(2)「大同団結運動」の訳は、用語集に従いました。(3)「藩閥政府」に括弧で説明を補足しました。不要な場合は削除してください。(2)「大成会」の定訳不明。「大成会」は政党というよりも、当時の院内会派であったので、訳語には"Party"ではなく"Group"を当てました。(4)「同調者」の訳について： 民党側は、保守系政党を後に「吏党」と蔑称で呼んでいることを考慮して、単なる「同調者 (sympsthizer)」よりも政府の言いなりであるという印象が出るように"follower"と訳しました。
sen.e: Winning majority in the first general election of the members of the House of Representatives in 1890, the parties demanding the democratic rights such as the Liberal Party (it was split then and reunited through the Great Merger Movement) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and etc. thought that the public was on their side and strengthened the attitude toward the han-dominated government (the members of former Choshu and Satsuma domains who played major part in the Meiji Restoration and had power after the restoration) which suppressed them and toward other conservative parties (the Taiseikai Group and so on) regarded as the followers of the government.
sen.cmt: 少し滑らかにしました。
sen.e: Winning majority in the first general election of the members of the House of Representatives in 1890, the parties demanding the democratic rights such as the Liberal Party (it was split then and reunited through the Great Merger Movement) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and etc. thought that the public was on their side and strengthened the attitude toward the han-dominated government (the members of former Choshu and Satsuma domains who played major part in the Meiji Restoration and had power after the restoration) which suppressed them and toward other conservative parties (the Taiseikai Group and so on) regarded as the followers of the government.

sen.j: 彼らは自分達こそが国民・民衆の代表であるとする意識から、「民党」という言葉を用い、反対勢力を政府官吏と癒着した勢力と看做して「吏党」と呼んで卑下した。
sen.e: They used the word "minto" to call themselves with the consciousness that they were the real representatives of the people, and they regarded their opponents as the group having a cozy relationship with the government officials and despised the group by calling it "rito" (literally, the parties of the government officials, it is the discriminatory term used by the members and supporters of minto).
sen.cmt: 「吏党」に説明を補足しました。不要な場合は削除してください。

sen.j: 中江兆民の伝記を書いた幸徳秋水の説によれば、中江が自由党 (日本)立憲自由党 (日本 1890-1898)（自由党再統合のための受け皿となった政党、後に「自由党」と改称）の機関紙『立憲自由新聞』の中で「民党・吏党」という呼称を用いたのが広まったとする説を唱えている。
sen.e: According to the opinion of Shusui KOTOKU who wrote the biography of Chomin NAKAE, Nakae first used the words "minto and rito" in "Rikken Jiyu Shinbun" (the Constitutional Liberal Press) which was the publication of the Liberal Party (in Japan) and the Constitutional Liberal Party (in Japan, 1890-1898, the party for the reunification of the Liberal Party, later renamed "the Liberal Party") and the words spread out later.
sen.cmt: (1)「幸徳秋水の説」： 幸徳秋水は中江兆民の弟子に当たることから、「説」といっても学説的なものではなく、主観的で私見に近いものであると考え、"theory"ではなく"opinion"としました。(2)「立憲自由新聞」について： 用語集に従いました。
sen.e: According to the opinion of Shusui KOTOKU, who wrote the biography of Chomin NAKAE, Nakae first used the words "Minto and Rito" in "Rikken Jiyu Shinbun" (the Constitutional Liberal Press) which was the publication of the Liberal Party (in Japan) and the Constitutional Liberal Party (the party for the reunification of the Liberal Party between 1890 to 1898 in Japan, later renamed "the Liberal Party") and the words spread out later.

sen.j: 民党は「民力休養・政費節減」を掲げて、超然主義を唱える政府と対決姿勢を示した。
sen.e: With the slogan "Recovery of the National Power and Reduction of the Administrative Expenditure", minto showed a strong attitude toward the government which advocated the doctrine of detachment.
sen.cmt: (1)「民力休養・政費節減」について： 歴史的に有名な用語ですが定訳不明でした。訳語は自作したものです。(2)「超然主義」について： 訳語リストでは"the doctrine of superiority"となっていますが、"the doctrine of detachment"の方が本来の意味に近いと考えたので、そちらを訳語としました。
sen.e: With the slogan "Recovery of the National Power and Reduction of the Administrative Expenditure," Minto showed a strong attitude toward the government which advocated the doctrine of detachment.

sen.j: これに対して政府は第2回衆議院議員総選挙の際に大規模な選挙干渉を行って民党の壊滅を計画するも、逆に大敗北を招く結果となった。
sen.e: On the other hand, the government planned to destroy minto by interfering in the second general election of the members of the House of Representatives in 1892 on a large scale, however, it ironically brought about its own total defeat.
sen.cmt: 読者の理解のために「第二回衆議院議員総選挙」の訳に西暦を補足しました。不要な場合は削除してください。
sen.e: On the other hand, the government planned to destroy Minto by interfering in the second general election of the members of the House of Representatives in 1892 on a large scale but ironically led to its own defeat.

sen.j: ところが、日清戦争や条約改正を巡って自由党と第2次伊藤内閣は協調関係に入り、却って立憲改進党と吏党が連携してそれを攻撃するという構図が形成されて民党に亀裂が生じた。
sen.e: However, because the Liberal Party entered into cooperative relationship with the Second Ito Cabinet about the first Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895 and the revision of unequal treaties, the Progressive Constitutional Party cooperated with rito and attacked them, as the result of this, cracks appeared in minto.
sen.cmt: 「日清戦争」について： 年号を付けない場合もありますが、読者の理解を助けるために付けました。
sen.e: However, because the Liberal Party entered into cooperative relationship with the Second Ito Cabinet about the First Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895 and the revision of unequal treaties, the Progressive Constitutional Party cooperated with Rito and attacked them and appeared in Minto.

sen.j: 逆に第2次松方内閣では立憲改進党の後身である進歩党_(明治)との事実上の連立体制（松隈内閣）が形成されてこれを自由党が攻撃するという構図も形成される。
sen.e: In the Second Matsukata Cabinet, the practical coalition cabinet was formed with the Progressive Party (in the Meiji Period) which was the Constitutional Progressive Party (the Showai Cabinet, Sho means Masayoshi MATSUKATA, Wai means Shigenobu OKUMA), and the Liberal Party attacked them.
sen.cmt: 「松隈内閣」に説明を補足しました。
sen.e: The practical coalition cabinet was formed as the Progressive Party (in the Meiji Period) which was the Constitutional Progressive Party (the Showai Cabinet (Sho was defined as Masayoshi MATSUKATA while Wai was Shigenobu OKUMA)) in the Second Matsukata Cabinet, and the Liberal Party attacked them.
sen.cmt: 文章を滑らかにしました。
sen.e: The practical coalition cabinet was formed as the Progressive Party (in the Meiji Period) which was the Constitutional Progressive Party (the Showai Cabinet (Sho was defined as Masayoshi MATSUKATA while Wai was Shigenobu OKUMA)) in the Second Matsukata Cabinet, and the Liberal Party attacked them.

sen.j: これによって民党のみならず、対立軸であった筈の吏党側にも動揺が走り、民党・吏党が入り乱れた政党再編の流れが強まった。
sen.e: Not only minto but also rito, which was minto's opponent at first, was shaken by this situation, and the movement to reorganize political parties in which minto and rito were mixed up strengthened.

Not only Minto but also Rito, which was Minto's opponent at the beginning, was shaken by this situation, and the movement to reorganize political parties which Minto and Rito put into confusion increased.
sen.cmt: MintoとRitoは大文字です。文章を滑らかにしました。
sen.e: Not only Minto but also Rito, which was Minto's opponent at the beginning, was shaken by this situation, and the movement to reorganize political parties which Minto and Rito put into confusion increased.

sen.j: それでも、犬養毅（立憲国民党非改革派→革新倶楽部）などの様にあくまでも民衆の代表であるという意識から「民党」という言葉に拘る政治家も存在したが、やがて自由党系と伊藤博文系官僚による立憲政友会と立憲改進党系と桂太郎派による立憲同志会（後の憲政会→立憲民政党）の2大政党に収斂されていくにつれて、民党という言葉は過去のものとなっていった。
sen.e: Although there were some politicians such as Tsuyoshi INUKAI (a member of the non-reform group in the Constitutional National Party, later he founded the Club of Innovation) and so on who stuck to the word "minto" with the consciousness that they would represent the people, as the movement to reorganize political parties concentrated on two major parties, namely the Constitutional Party of Political Friends which consisted of the Liberal Party and government officials under Hirobumi ITO, and The Constitutional Association of Friends (later, the Constitutional Association, and it changed again into the Constitutional Democratic Party) which consisted of the Constitutional Progressive Party and the group of Taro KATSURA, the word "Minto" faded away.
